EV Battery Thermal Management: An Interactive Analysis

Translating academic research into an explorable experience.

The Thermal Challenge

High-performance Lithium-Ion battery packs, the heart of modern electric vehicles, generate significant heat during operation. Without an effective thermal management system (TMS), temperatures can quickly rise beyond safe limits, posing a risk of thermal runaway, reducing battery lifespan, and compromising safety. This analysis explores different cooling strategies to mitigate this risk, especially under demanding Indian environmental conditions.

74°C
Max Temperature (Uncooled)

At peak load (2.3C) & 35°C ambient.

20-45°C
Safe Operating Range

Target for optimal performance and longevity.

>60°C
High-Risk Zone

Increased risk of degradation and thermal runaway.

Interactive Simulation Dashboard

Select the parameters below to explore how different cooling solutions perform under various conditions.

Analysis & Insights

Coolant Performance:

    Solutions Deep Dive

    Forced Air Cooling

    Uses fans to circulate ambient air over the battery cells. The most effective configuration tested was a dual-fan setup (one intake, one exhaust).

    Pros: Simple, low cost, easy to maintain.

    Cons: Limited cooling capacity, less effective in high ambient temperatures, can introduce dust and moisture.

    Phase Change Material (PCM)

    A passive system where a material (like RT-42 paraffin wax) absorbs heat as it melts, keeping the battery temperature stable at its melting point.

    Pros: Passive (no energy consumption), uniform temperature.

    Cons: Low thermal conductivity limits heat absorption rate, making it ineffective for high heat loads. One-time use per thermal cycle until it re-solidifies.

    Liquid Cooling

    Circulates a coolant (like water or glycol) through a cold plate in direct contact with the battery pack, transferring heat to a radiator or chiller.

    Pros: Highly effective, precise temperature control, high heat transfer capacity.

    Cons: Complex, higher cost, potential for leaks, consumes parasitic power.

    Conclusions & Recommendations

    The analysis definitively shows that a thermal management system is mandatory for this battery pack to operate safely under realistic conditions.

    Liquid cooling is the superior technical solution, demonstrating a 47% reduction in peak temperature and consistently maintaining the battery within its optimal range for both safety and longevity. This makes it the recommended choice for high-performance and long-life applications.

    Air cooling presents a viable, low-cost alternative. While it cannot maintain optimal temperatures, it successfully reduces peak temperatures by up to 24%, bringing them into a safe, acceptable range. This could be suitable for applications where cost is a primary constraint and peak performance is intermittent.

    PCM was found to be ineffective for this application due to its inability to handle the high heat flux generated during peak operation.

    Interactive report based on the thesis by Narayan Ralhan & Suprith C Shekar, RV College of Engineering.
